channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: 2 Drone Strikes in Pakistan Are Said to Kill Militant Suspects
item.description: The strikes in the northwest were believed to have been carried out by American aircraft, a Pakistani security official said.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Viewers Mostly Give Thumbs Up for ‘The Interview’
item.description: By midday on Friday, more than 300,000 people in China had seen the film about a plot to assassinate Kim Jong-un of North Korea and the reviews, by and large, were favorable.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: "The Interview" portrays a C.I.A. plot to assassinate the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, played by the actor Randall Park.

item.title: Palestinian Wounds 2 Israeli Police Officers in Jerusalem
item.description: The assailant approached the officers after dawn prayers at Al Aqsa Mosque, stabbed one in the neck and injured the other in the ensuing struggle, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Jill Robinson on Animals and Empathy in Asia
item.description: Ms. Robinson discusses Animals Asia Foundation’s work to end bear bile farming in China and Vietnam, changing cultural attitudes in Asia and the bear that reached out to her.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Jill Robinson, founder of the Animals Asia Foundation.

item.title: Loss by Taiwan Governing Party Raises Fears That Ties With China Will Sour
item.description: When the opposition Democratic Progressive Party last held power, it presided over a period of increased tensions with the mainland.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Saudi Antiterrorism Court to Try Women Held for Driving
item.description: Two Saudi women detained for nearly a month after they defied edicts that prohibit women from driving were referred on Thursday to a court established to try terrorism cases.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Set to Cut Force in Darfur as Fighting Rises
item.description: United Nations officials say their forces are routinely attacked by Sudanese forces and their proxies and that it is virtually impossible for their peacekeepers to remain without Sudan’s blessing.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Women and children in North Darfur, where Sudanese soldiers were accused of mass rape. Human rights groups say that peacekeepers botched an investigation into the matter.

item.title: SÃo LuÍs Journal: Decline of a Political Family Opens the Way for a Shift in Brazil
item.description: As José Sarney prepares to leave his Senate seat representing Maranhão State, a profound power shift could be underway.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bust of José Sarney, a senator and former president of Brazil, at the Convento das Mercês. Mr. Sarney's name and image are ubiquitous in São Luís, the capital of Maranhão State.

item.title: For Sri Lankan President, Renounced by Aides, Confidence of Re-election Dims
item.description: Defectors from the cabinet of President Mahinda Rajapaksa have bragged about plotting their desertion under his nose.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: President Mahinda Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka, center front, has set elections for Jan. 8, two years before the end of his second term.

item.title: Death Sentence in Mauritania for Islam ‘Insult’
item.description: The man, Mohamed Cheikh Ould Mkhaitir, 28, was arrested a year ago for writing an article that was interpreted by some as being critical of the Prophet Muhammad.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Hong Kong: Police Detain Pro-Democracy Protesters
item.description: The police used pepper spray and batons overnight to break up the protest in the Mong Kok neighborhood, a police statement said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sony Streams ‘The Interview’ on YouTube, Google Play and Xbox
item.description: In getting behind “The Interview,” Google and Microsoft joined what had become more a campaign to defend free speech against foreign intimidation than a business initiative.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES
item.media:description: Google offered “The Interview” in its Play store as well as on YouTube.

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Human Costs of the Forever Wars, Enough to Fill a Bookshelf
item.description: Books that have grown out of America’s wars in Afghanistan and Iraq illuminate the nature of those battles, the people who are fighting them and America itself.
item.dc:creator: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI
item.media:description: From left, Phil Klay, Kayla Williams, Michael Pitre, Brian Castner, Matt Gallagher and Brandon Willitts.

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Plans for More Settler Homes Move Forward
item.description: Israel has given preliminary approval for the construction of 243 homes on West Bank land that Israel annexed to Jerusalem, officials said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Boy Accused of Insulting President Is Arrested
item.description: The newspaper Hurriyet reported that the 16-year-old high-school student, identified only by his initials M.E.A., had been arrested Wednesday in Konya after making a speech at a student protest a day earlier
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sweden: Arson Attack on Mosque Injures 5, Police Say
item.description: The attack comes amid an intense debate over immigration that has pitted Sweden’s far right against mainstream parties intent on preserving Sweden’s liberal immigration policy.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Fighters Clash With Troops Defending Oil Sites
item.description: Islamist militia fighters killed at least 22 soldiers on Thursday during a surprise attack in which they used speedboats in a bid to seize some of Libya’s main oil facilities, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Bomb Kills 2 in Army Vehicle in Sinai Peninsula
item.description: A roadside bomb struck an army vehicle late Thursday, killing an officer and a soldier in the Sinai Peninsula, security officials said.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Crowds Gather as ‘The Interview’ Begins Screening in 331 Theaters
item.description: The film had improbably become a symbol of free speech over the last week as hackers managed to get it withdrawn from theaters and then watched it open after all.
item.dc:creator: By BROOKS BARNES and MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:credit: Andrew Renneisen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A full house for the 12:10 p.m. showing Thursday of the Sony film “The Interview” at Williamsburg Cinemas in Brooklyn.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bilingual Nationhood, Canadian-Style
item.description: America should look north for help with its immigration debate.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND
